 (Draw a card.)

messages.content: holy shit that's an incredible beta

Kinda nice for putting shield chargers in stasis. Planning is so much better as a pickup, there usually isn't enough draw to support losing two cards from hand. Needs bunch of other cards to start giving free value, like warcry.
:Flushied:

If only there was some way to have draw with this card. Oh yeah, the upgrade. Card is like C tier unupgraded S tier upgraded. Also guardian has some decent draw, and you can always take this after you get the draw.

I think planning is a better earlygame pick, but it can hurt in late game since getting stasis slots is a long process, filling 2 with something you don't want in there can take up 2/3 of your stasis slots for 2 turns.
Like if it grabs strike/defend, or gem cannon in the beginning of a boss fight
I do think Suspension does get outclassed by <future plans> though, as it still does stasis this turn.

I'm usually fine waiting a few turns for time sifter tbh, it's not the #1 priority. I could see upgrading it for Neow and maybe right before the act 3 boss, but I would never want it upgraded before then.
is future plans better than well laid plans
Imo no, although it does have a similar effect where you can use it to retain a 0 cost card in hand.
future plans doesn't enable grand finale
well laid plans enables the entire discard strategy and grand finale is unplayable without it

WLP is really good because the amount of turn dependent defensive cards the silent has. Piercing wail and wraith form as the highlights. It also has a more immediate effect, compared to future planning usually taking a few turns to get the card you put in back. I think future plans has a higher ceiling (ie. if you plan around putting cards in knowing you'll get them back for certain turns, or if you have a lot of accelerate support) but WLP is universally more helpful.

Suspension+ is the easiest and most straightforward entry point to the infinite combo archetype for Guardian, because it is a common, but despite popular belief is by no means the only way that archetype exists. (And is, in my opinion, unquestionably the most powerful thing to be doing at least at <10 Ascension.) There are plenty of substitutes for it - just Quartz, Exploit Gems, and of course the usual Flash of Steel and Finesse - but it is the easiest to get your hands on.

Almost any reasonable gem into a Suspension+ is going to be good enough to loop with - shiv, ruby, certainly Cirtrine, thorns if you are a maniac. The pleasant benefit of Suspension is that while looping it also lets you put a couple cards into stasis, acting as a sort of virtual card remove to prune your deck smaller to reach the loop. It also enables Temporal Strike/Quartz which is another very easy loop component. (That can also be very easily enabled by the 0 cost recurring weaken/attack that suspends itself. )

There are some times early in a run where you might not be able to afford picking up a Suspension non-plus, if you are headed into an Act 1 elite and have already weakened your deck in anticipation of the future (e.g., skipped a lot and not found a "carry" card or relic to get you to your infinite). Don't worry too much about skipping it then; you will likely be able to find replacement. That said, upgrading this at a campfire (and gemming it!) usually becomes an immediate top priority, sometimes even changing your path plan.

There have been calls to nerf Supsension+ to no longer be a 0 cost draw card. While this would make it, and the Guardian overall, certainly more balanced and expose more of the card pool to usability, it doesn't seem like the Downfall community has fully embraced the infinite combo as the only way to play Guardian. Therefore I would argue that the current state of Suspension is not, in practice, causing the class to be less fun, and it would be wiser and more generous to leave it as is - until and unless many other players both a) play infinite on Guardian consistently and b) dislike feeling forced into such a playstyle.

In my early Guardian days, I didn't like this card very much since it removed 2 cards from your hand to do almost nothing. While that is a downside, the control over stasis is something I've come to appreciate a lot more, as well as consider taking for the upgrade to fix that issue. I don't approach this card from an infinite-combo perspective, by the way.

If the recently-proposed change to make it block/gain block on upgrade without draw goes through, I'm not sure how much I'll take it, as removing that many cards from hand for minimal benefit doesn't seem great.
IMO I would probably still take like one copy of it, but only one, and with accelerate as well

I actually just haven't played with this card very much. I'm a huge fan of planning, reroute, recover, future plans, and sentry blast, all of which help fill stasis slots very efficiently. In comparison suspension (unupgraded) has less of an immediate impact, and uses up 2 cards from your hand. It's also a low impact skill, which is awful in act 1, an act that guardian already naturally struggles with due to the defensive nature of the character and their relatively weak starting deck/relic (in terms of frontloaded damage). Sure, as you approach late act 2 and beyond, suspension+ becomes a very attractive card as either a value pick or part of an infinte engine, but by that time, I at least usually already have a large enough deck that going infinite isn't an option anymore. A lot of that is personal preference, I just don't find going infinite very fun or interesting, and I really enjoy building 35+ card toolbox style decks that can very flexibly adapt their gameplan for each different kind of fight. I also do believe that trying to keep a deck thin enough to go infinite gets punished pretty heavily at high ascension when you need to have a stronger early game to deal with improved enemy patterns and ascenders bane.

Suspension is a very "airy" card, it doesn't do very much when you draw it, and really needs a lot of support to become more than the sum of it's parts. With the right gem, or particularly strong cards to cheat into stasis with it (shield charger, expensive cards) it can become a bigger part of your gameplan, but it's really unexciting normally. That makes picking it pretty contextual, as you have to make sure that you can upgrade and/or socket it at a campfire ASAP. The upgrade is probably one of the biggest improvements in downfall, as it gets rid of the card disadvantage, gives you better selection about what to put into stasis, and of course enables infinites. Ink bottle and letter opener both help with make this less airy.
